M.G.L. c. 212, \u00a7 3.proposition: This Court has jurisdiction over this action pursuant to M.G.L. c. 212, § 3 and M.G.L. c. 185C, § 3, as this matter involves landlord-tenant claims arising within the City of Boston.

M.G.L. c. 185C, \u00a7 3.proposition: This Court has jurisdiction over this action pursuant to M.G.L. c. 212, § 3 and M.G.L. c. 185C, § 3, as this matter involves landlord-tenant claims arising within the City of Boston.

105 C.M.R. 410.000.proposition: Plaintiff contacted the City of Boston Inspectional Services Department, which inspected the property and documented water intrusion and additional housing code violations pursuant to 105 C.M.R. 410.000 (State Sanitary Code, Chapter II).

M.G.L. c. 186, \u00a7 14.proposition: Under M.G.L. c. 186, § 14, a landlord who directly or indirectly interferes with a tenant’s quiet enjoyment of leased premises is liable for damages or statutory penalties.

M.G.L. c. 186, \u00a7 18.proposition: Defendant’s retaliatory behavior in threatening nonrenewal of the lease after Plaintiff sought enforcement of building code obligations also constitutes an interference and violation of M.G.L. c. 186, § 14 and M.G.L. c. 186, § 18.

Blackett v. Olanoff, 371 Mass. 714 (1977.proposition: The covenant protects tenants from serious interferences with their tenancy caused by the landlord’s acts or omissions, whether deliberate or negligent.
Blackett v. Olanoff, 371 Mass. 714 (1977.support_reasoning: The court explicitly rejects any requirement of intentional misconduct and states that a landlord breaches the covenant of quiet enjoyment when serious interferences are the natural and probable consequence of what the landlord did, failed to do, or permitted to be done. The opinion emphasizes that the landlord’s conduct, not intent, is controlling and cites prior cases involving negligent or omissive conduct, thereby supporting the proposition that the covenant protects tenants from serious interferences caused by the landlord’s acts or omissions, whether deliberate or negligent.
Blackett v. Olanoff, 371 Mass. 714 (1977.relevant_excerpt: “There are occasions, however, where a landlord has not intended to violate a tenant’s rights, but there was nevertheless a breach of the landlord’s covenant of quiet enjoyment which flowed as the natural and probable consequence of what the landlord did, what he failed to do, or what he permitted to be done… Although some of our opinions have spoken of particular action or inaction by a landlord as showing a presumed intention to evict, the landlord’s conduct, and not his intentions, is controlling.”

Simon v. Solomon, 385 Mass. 91 (1982).proposition: The covenant protects tenants from serious interferences with their tenancy caused by the landlord’s acts or omissions, whether deliberate or negligent.
Simon v. Solomon, 385 Mass. 91 (1982).support_reasoning: The court explicitly explains the meaning of “quiet enjoyment” and notes that, under both the common-law covenant and G.L. c. 186, § 14, liability no longer turns on malicious intent but on whether the landlord’s acts or omissions cause serious interferences with the tenancy. It cites prior cases holding landlords liable whenever the natural and probable consequence of their conduct is an interruption of the tenant’s rights, thereby encompassing both deliberate and negligent (or at least non-intentional) conduct.
Simon v. Solomon, 385 Mass. 91 (1982).relevant_excerpt: “The phrase ‘quiet enjoyment’ is a familiar term in landlord-tenant law, signifying the tenant’s right to freedom from serious interferences with his tenancy — acts or omissions that ‘impair the character and value of the leased premises.’… Although early cases applying the covenant of quiet enjoyment required intent on the part of the landlord… more recent decisions have imposed liability whenever the ‘natural and probable consequence’ of a landlord’s action was interruption of the tenant’s rights…. When the Legislature chose the words ‘quiet enjoyment’… it must have intended to incorporate these cases into the statute.”

Hemingway v. O\u2019Brien, 378 Mass. 369.proposition: Defendant’s failure to maintain watertight, habitable conditions breaches statutory and common-law obligations of habitability and quiet enjoyment.
Hemingway v. O\u2019Brien, 378 Mass. 369.support_reasoning: This opinion concerns discharge of an accommodation maker on a promissory note under UCC § 3‑606 and the effect of an express reservation of rights when extending time for payment. It does not address landlord‑tenant law, statutory or common‑law obligations of habitability, or quiet enjoyment, nor does it involve failure to maintain watertight or habitable premises. Thus it cannot be authoritative support for the stated habitability/quiet enjoyment proposition.
Hemingway v. O\u2019Brien, 378 Mass. 369.relevant_excerpt: Under the Uniform Commercial Code, as enacted in G. L. c. 106, § 3-606, an accommodation maker of a note is discharged from liability to the extent that the holder of the note "without express reservation of rights" agrees to suspend the right to enforce the instrument against the party accommodated. … However, where the extension is accompanied by an express reservation of rights, the surety is not prejudiced, because he can immediately pay the instrument and exercise his right of recourse against the principal debtor.

Boston Housing Auth. v. Hemingway, 363 M.raw_text: Boston Housing Auth. v. Hemingway, 363 Mass. 184 (1973)
Boston Housing Auth. v. Hemingway, 363 M.proposition: Defendant’s failure to maintain watertight, habitable conditions breaches statutory and common-law obligations of habitability and quiet enjoyment.
Boston Housing Auth. v. Hemingway, 363 M.support_reasoning: The opinion (even in this concurring/dissenting section) expressly recognizes that Massachusetts law should abandon caveat emptor and impose on landlords an obligation, grounded in statutes and common law, to provide dwelling units that meet minimum standards of fitness for human habitation, with the tenant’s rent obligation interdependent with that duty. While the author prefers to frame the duty as an implied agreement to comply with the State Sanitary Code rather than a broader "implied warranty of habitability," he clearly endorses a landlord obligation to maintain habitable, code‑compliant premises for the benefit of tenants. This supports the proposition that failure to maintain watertight, habitable conditions breaches statutory and common-law obligations of habitability and quiet enjoyment, even though "watertight" is not specifically mentioned in this excerpt.
Boston Housing Auth. v. Hemingway, 363 M.relevant_excerpt: I would reverse that rule and hold instead (a) that the various statutes, ordinances, by-laws, rules, regulations and codes prescribing minimum standards for dwelling units impose on the landlord, for the benefit of his tenants, an obligation to comply with those minimum standards, and (b) that by renting such a unit the landlord impliedly agrees with his tentant (i) that at the time of the renting the unit complies with those standards and (ii) that during the term of the renting he will do whatever such legal provisions require him to do for compliance with such standards.

Armstrong v. Cuffley, 389 Mass. 351 (198.proposition: Dampness, leakage, and unsanitary conditions constitute interference with quiet enjoyment where they materially impair the character and value of the premises.
Armstrong v. Cuffley, 389 Mass. 351 (198.support_reasoning: The opinion concerns criminal convictions for possession of a controlled substance and negligent operation of a motor vehicle, focusing on evidentiary issues, severance, and sufficiency of the evidence. It does not address landlord-tenant law, quiet enjoyment, or conditions such as dampness, leakage, or unsanitary premises. Therefore, it provides no authority for the stated proposition about interference with quiet enjoyment.
Armstrong v. Cuffley, 389 Mass. 351 (198.relevant_excerpt: [No relevant excerpt available: the opinion does not discuss landlord-tenant issues, quiet enjoyment, or conditions like dampness, leakage, or unsanitary premises.]

Jablonski v. Casey, 64 Mass. App. Ct. 74.raw_text: Jablonski v. Casey, 64 Mass. App. Ct. 744 (2005)
Jablonski v. Casey, 64 Mass. App. Ct. 74.proposition: Dampness, leakage, and unsanitary conditions constitute interference with quiet enjoyment where they materially impair the character and value of the premises.
Jablonski v. Casey, 64 Mass. App. Ct. 74.support_reasoning: The opinion discusses the covenant/statutory right of quiet enjoyment only in very general terms and finds no interference with the tenant’s quiet enjoyment on these facts. It does not address, much less hold, that dampness, leakage, or unsanitary conditions constitute interference where they materially impair the character and value of the premises; those kinds of conditions are mentioned only in a string-cite to other cases as examples of ‘significant defects’ for habitability, not as a quiet-enjoyment rule in this case. Thus this decision does not itself establish the specific proposition stated.
Jablonski v. Casey, 64 Mass. App. Ct. 74.relevant_excerpt: “Casey counterclaimed that York breached her covenant of quiet enjoyment. Similar to the warranty of habitability, during the rental of any residential premises, there exists an implied covenant and a statutory right of quiet enjoyment. See Simon v. Solomon, 385 Mass. 91, 102 (1982); G. L. c. 186, § 14. We have interpreted this obligation to mean that the covenant of quiet enjoyment protects a tenant from serious interference with her tenancy. See Doe v. New Bedford Hous. Authy., 417 Mass. 273, 285 (1994). … We see no evidence in the record before us of interference with Casey’s quiet enjoyment of the premises.”}

Al-Ziab v. Mourgis, 424 Mass. 847 (1997).proposition: Defendant’s inaction following notice from Plaintiff and the City constitutes “direct or indirect interference” as defined by statute and case law.
Al-Ziab v. Mourgis, 424 Mass. 847 (1997).support_reasoning: The opinion interprets G.L. c. 186, § 14 and explains that a landlord’s failure to act after having notice of a problem can constitute the kind of ‘direct or indirect’ interference with quiet enjoyment covered by the statute, provided there is at least negligent conduct. The court explicitly notes prior cases holding that a landlord’s failure to repair known defects or to take corrective measures after notice can violate § 14, and clarifies that in the lead-paint context liability requires showing the landlord had notice or reason to know and failed to act. This aligns with the proposition that inaction following notice may amount to ‘direct or indirect interference.’
Al-Ziab v. Mourgis, 424 Mass. 847 (1997).relevant_excerpt: We noted that a landlord’s failure “to repair defects of which he has notice in leased premises is an omission which frequently has been deemed to violate § 14.” See Cruz, supra at 789, citing Simon v. Solomon, supra at 103 (failure to control floods in tenant’s apartment); Darmetko v. Boston Hous. Auth., 378 Mass. 758, 761 (1979) (failure to repair leaky roof); Dorgan v. Loukas, 19 Mass. App. Ct. 959, 960 (1985) (failure to bring apartment into habitable condition and keep it so). … [T]o obtain relief under § 14 for a claim of lead paint poisoning it must be demonstrated that the landlord had notice of or reason to know of the presence of lead and failed to take appropriate corrective measures.

Doe v. New Bedford Hous. Auth., 417 Mass.raw_text: Doe v. New Bedford Hous. Auth., 417 Mass. 273 (1994)
Doe v. New Bedford Hous. Auth., 417 Mass.proposition: Defendant’s inaction following notice from Plaintiff and the City constitutes “direct or indirect interference” as defined by statute and case law.
Doe v. New Bedford Hous. Auth., 417 Mass.case_name: Doe v. New Bedford Housing Authority
Doe v. New Bedford Hous. Auth., 417 Mass.support_reasoning: The court holds that a landlord’s omission—failure to take available measures after notice of serious criminal activity—can constitute a “direct or indirect” interference with tenants’ quiet enjoyment under G.L. c. 186, § 14. The opinion explicitly links the housing authority’s standing idle after tenant complaints with potential liability for breaching the covenant. Thus, it squarely supports the proposition that defendant’s inaction following notice can be treated as indirect interference under the statute and related case law.
Doe v. New Bedford Hous. Auth., 417 Mass.relevant_excerpt: “In analyzing whether there is a breach of the covenant, we examine the landlord’s conduct and not his intentions… the breach is a ‘natural and probable consequence of what the landlord did, what he failed to do, or what he permitted to be done.’… [I]f the defendant has failed to take any measures… to remove unwelcome persons from the property that it owns and controls, and the presence of those persons seriously interferes with the tenancy, then the defendant may be liable for a breach of the covenant of quiet enjoyment.”

Lowery v. Robinson, 13 Mass. App. Ct. 98.raw_text: Lowery v. Robinson, 13 Mass. App. Ct. 982 (1982)
Lowery v. Robinson, 13 Mass. App. Ct. 98.proposition: Defendant’s retaliatory behavior in threatening nonrenewal of the lease after Plaintiff sought enforcement of building code obligations also constitutes an interference and violation of M.G.L. c. 186, § 14 and M.G.L. c. 186, § 18.
Lowery v. Robinson, 13 Mass. App. Ct. 98.support_reasoning: The opinion deals with a landlord’s failure to provide heat and resulting liability under G.L. c. 186, § 14 for breach of quiet enjoyment; it does not address retaliatory conduct, threats of nonrenewal, or G.L. c. 186, § 18 at all. The case is about strict liability for failure to provide heat and limitations on rent increases, not about retaliation for a tenant’s assertion of building code rights. Thus it does not provide authority for the specific proposition concerning retaliatory threats of nonrenewal violating §§ 14 and 18.
Lowery v. Robinson, 13 Mass. App. Ct. 98.relevant_excerpt: It was claimed that the defendants had violated those portions of G. L. c. 186, § 14, as amended by St. 1974, c. 192, § 1, which impose civil liability on a landlord “who willfully or intentionally fails to furnish . . . heat. . . or . . . who directly or indirectly interferes with the quiet enjoyment of any residential premises by the occupant . . . .” … On the facts found by the judge, the tenant was entitled on the quiet enjoyment claim to (a) a declaration that the landlords had violated G. L. c. 186, § 14…

Spence v. O'Brien, 15 Mass. App. Ct. 489.raw_text: Spence v. O'Brien, 15 Mass. App. Ct. 489 (1983)
Spence v. O'Brien, 15 Mass. App. Ct. 489.proposition: Defendant’s retaliatory behavior in threatening nonrenewal of the lease after Plaintiff sought enforcement of building code obligations also constitutes an interference and violation of M.G.L. c. 186, § 14 and M.G.L. c. 186, § 18.
Spence v. O'Brien, 15 Mass. App. Ct. 489.support_reasoning: The opinion in Spence v. O'Brien concerns eviction from public housing for permitting drug activity and addresses issues of good cause, notice to quit, grievance procedures, and availability of defenses under G.L. c. 239, § 8A. It does not discuss retaliatory conduct by a landlord, threats of nonrenewal, or any claims under G.L. c. 186, §§ 14 or 18. Therefore, it does not provide authority for the proposition that retaliatory threats of nonrenewal after a tenant seeks building code enforcement violate those statutes.
Spence v. O'Brien, 15 Mass. App. Ct. 489.relevant_excerpt:
The record before us reveals that all the procedural requirements set out in 24 C.F.R. § 866.54 through and including § 866.58 (1982) were followed. O’Brien’s remaining contentions concerning whether the panel’s decision constituted good cause have been answered in Spence v. Gormley, supra.

O’Brien argues that the trial judge was in error in refusing to allow her to raise the defense of uninhabitable conditions under G. L. c. 239, § 8A.... The judge was not in error in concluding that the defenses were not available to O’Brien.
